Description: Mould-made scaraboid in glazed composition; back in the shape of a lion couchant; underside bearing a very eroded cryptographic inscription with hieroglyphic signs arranged vertically consisting from top to bottom of sun-disc, men-draughtboard and owl (only upper part of owl preserved, but complete device illustrated in Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no.104) with sun-disc above back; inscription possibly stamped; longitudinally pierced; glaze lost; core yellow coarse in texture; worn and lower part broken off.
Curator's comments: Lion scaraboids belong to a common series produced at Naukratis (on the ‘Scarab Factory’ productions, see Webb forthcoming). Moulds to produce lion scaraboids were discovered in Naukratis: BM 1896,0610.16 and BM 1896,0610.17. Numerous couchant lion scaraboids were discovered in Naukratis (see for example the ones illustrated in Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, nos. 50, 654, 69, 80, 92, 99, 104). The underside of lion scaraboids usually bears possibly the name of Amun-Ra, written in a cryptic way (or less likely an imitation of a royal name). This scaraboid belongs to a type widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B63-67, see especially B65 for this piece). Though the hieroglyphic signs could have just some magical value, it seems more plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun-Ra (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). The lion shape of the scaraboid can be associated with solar deties. Lions were used to write the name of Ra during the Late Period, as the lion is a phonetic equivalent Rw (De Wit 1951, 138ff). De Wit, C. 1951, Le rôle et le sens du lion dans l’Egypte ancienne, Leiden. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 104) (now broken)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 103, Type XXVIII B65)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.077) (phase 3)
Condition: Rather poor, eroded and base chipped
